journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Decentralized output feedback stabilization of large-scale uncertain nonlinear systems

contrib-group.aff: Key Laboratory of Measurement and Control of CSE, Ministry of Education, School of Automation, Southeast University, China

author-notes.corresp: Jun-yong Zhai, School of Automation, Southeast University, Nanjing, Jiangsu 210096, China. E-mail: jyzhai@seu.edu.cn

abstract.p: This paper addresses the problem of decentralized global stabilization by output feedback for a class of uncertain large-scale nonlinear systems. A new design method based on the homogeneous domination approach and finite-time stabilization technique is developed, which leads to global output feedback stabilization for large-scale uncertain nonlinear systems under a homogeneous growth condition. Firstly, a homogeneous observer and controller is constructed for the nominal system without the perturbing nonlinearities for each subsystem. Then, a scaling gain is introduced into the homogeneous observers and controllers to globally stabilize the uncertain nonlinear systems.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: An important motivation for the design of decentralized schemes is that the information exchange between subsystems is not needed; thus, the individual subsystem controller is very simple and uses only locally available information. Decentralized control of large-scale systems has received considerable interest in the nonlinear control community. A large body of literature on the decentralized control of large-scale systems is referred to by Siljak.1 Earlier works on decentralized control have focused on the control of large-scale linear systems.2–4 However, most of the practical systems are inherently nonlinear. Recently, there has been an increasing interest in developing control scheme of large-scale nonlinear systems.5–12 In many practical situations, complete state measurements are not available at each individual subsystem for decentralized control; consequently, one has to consider decentralized feedback control based on measurements only or design decentralized observers to estimate the state of individual subsystems that can be used for estimated state feedback control. There has been a strong research effort in the literature towards the development of decentralized control schemes based on output feedback via construction of decentralized observers. Recent works7–11 have focused on the decentralized output feedback problem for a number of special classes of nonlinear systems. In the nonlinear output feedback setting, however, most of the results for large-scale systems consider only those interconnected by their outputs, with limited results for those that consider the interconnection of unmeasurable states. Zheng13 considered nonlinear functions that could depend on unbounded unmeasurable states, however, the result is a local one due to the use of a quadratic method. Wu14 considered the problem of decentralized iterative learning control for a class of large-scale interconnected dynamical systems.

However, most of the existing works only consider the asymptotic stabilization that makes the trajectories of the system converge asymptotically to the equilibrium as the time goes to infinity. This paper focuses on the problem of global finite-time output feedback stabilization for a class of uncertain nonlinear systems. Due to fast convergence and good performance on robustness and disturbance rejection, a number of researchers have studied the finite-time stability problem and obtained some interesting results.15–19 The Lyapunov theory for finite-time stability was employed by Bhat and Bernstein,15,16 which provides a basic tool for analysis and synthesis of nonlinear control systems. Some results on the state feedback finite-time stabilization of dynamic systems were achieved by a number of papers.15,16,18,19 Compared to the state feedback case, there are fewer results dealing with output feedback finite-time stabilization. An interesting result was given by Hong et al.17 whereby the finite-time output feedback stabilization of the double integrator system was achieved by developing a novel homogeneous controller. However, most of the finite-time stabilization results available are only applicable to two- (2D) or three-dimensional (3D) control systems. In the higher dimensional case, continuous state feedback control laws were derived to achieve local finite-time stabilization for triangular nonlinear systems.18 A global finite-time stabilization of uncertain nonlinear systems with a lower-triangular form was achieved by Hölder continuous state feedback by Huang et al.19 Hong et al.20 constructed a finite-time stabilizer for nonlinear systems in the p normal form with parametric uncertainties. Extending the design of Huang et al.19 a global finite-time stabilization was achieved by continuous but non-smooth state feedback for uncertain nonlinear systems with a lower-triangular form.21 Recently, by extending the technique of adding one power integrator22 and a special continuous observer design, a dynamic output feedback controller was explicitly developed to render a class of nonlinear systems globally finite-time stable.23 More recently, the problem of global finite-time stabilization via output feedback was considered for a class of upper-triangular systems whose output gain was unknown.24 In addition, Zhai and Qian25 addressed the problem of global output feedback stabilization for a class of nonlinear systems whose output functions were not precisely known.

The nonlinearities of the systems considered in this paper are neither linearly growing nor Lipschitz in unmeasurable states, which makes most of existing methods inapplicable to solve the problem. An important fact presently known about the global output feedback stabilization of nonlinear systems is that the nonlinear functions cannot grow too fast due to the finite escape time phenomenon as demonstrated by Mazenc et al.26 The aim of this paper is to tackle the challenging question and provide a solution to the problem of decentralized output feedback stabilization for large-scale uncertain nonlinear systems. To accomplish this goal, a homogeneous observer and controller is designed for each nominal system. Then, a scaling gain will be introduced into the homogeneous observers and controllers to render the interconnected nonlinear systems globally stable. The homogeneous domination approach not only completely removes the linear growth condition, which has been the common assumption for global output feedback stabilization, but also provides a new perspective to deal with the finite-time output feedback control problem for large-scale uncertain nonlinear systems.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. The preliminaries and problem statement are given in the next section. The main results are presented in the following section. An example is then given to show the validity of the proposed scheme. The conclusions appear in the final section.

sec.title: Preliminaries and problem statement
sec.p: This section contains several useful definitions and lemmas which play important roles in this paper and a statement of the problem that this paper will examine.

sec.title: Main results
sec.p: In this section, a novel systematic design method, namely the homogeneous domination approach, is developed for the global output feedback stabilization of uncertain nonlinear systems. The homogeneous domination approach consists of two parts.

list-item.p: A homogeneous observer and controller is constructed for the nominal system without the perturbing nonlinearities, whose construction is genuinely nonlinear rather than linear. Specifically, a state feedback control law is recursively designed for the nominal system. Then, a homogeneous observer is constructed with a set of constant gains to be determined later. Finally, the observer gains will be selected to guarantee that the closed-loop system is globally finite-time stable.

Based on the homogeneous observers/controllers, the scaled output feedback controllers are designed which can effectively dominate the nonlinearities by taking advantage of the homogeneous structure of the controllers.

Then a homogeneous observer is constructed with a set of constant gains to be determined later. Finally, the observer gains will be selected to guarantee that the closed-loop system is globally finite-time stable.

sec.title: Illustrative example
sec.p: In this section, an example illustrates the effectiveness of the proposed scheme for the uncertain nonlinear systems.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This paper considers the problem of decentralized global stabilization by output feedback for a class of uncertain large-scale nonlinear systems. It is shown that the decentralized global stabilization problem is solvable using the homogeneous observers and controllers, which can be explicitly constructed. Firstly, a homogeneous observer and controller is constructed for each nominal subsystem without the perturbing nonlinearities. Then a scaling gain is introduced into the output feedback stabilizers to globally stabilize a class of uncertain interconnected nonlinear systems. Simulation results on a numerical example illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed scheme.
